3762867243.given_title: AI image generation tech can now create life-wrecking deepfakes with ease
3762867243.resolved_title: AI image generation tech can now create life-wrecking deepfakes with ease
3762867243.excerpt: If you're one of the billions of people who have posted pictures of themselves on social media over the past decade, it may be time to rethink that behavior.

1.caption: This is John. He doesn't exist. But AI can easily put a photo of him in any situation we want. And the same process can apply to real people with just a few real photos pulled from social media.

2.caption: Enlarge / These inoffensive, social-media-style images of "John" were used as the training data that our AI used to put him in more compromising positions.

11.caption: Enlarge / This AI-generated "photo" of ancient Greek philosopher Heraclitus pulls from what the AI model knows about photos of old men and depictions of ancient Greek culture that were found in its training data set.

12.caption: Enlarge / Google researchers used cute Corgi dogs to illustrate Dreambooth's capabilities to avoid obvious ethical issues about training AI models with humans.

13.caption: Enlarge / An assortment of robot portraits generated by Stable Diffusion.

14.caption: Enlarge / An illustration of MIT's PhotoGuard process that guards against AI photo editing. A similar adversarial method might prevent AI from being trained on certain images.

2864300397.given_title: 2020 Guide to Synthetic Media | Paperspace Blog
2864300397.excerpt: From deepfakes and virtual celebrities to "fake news," we'll cover popular cases of media synthesis and the research publications detailing how it's done. Synthetic media is an exciting new area of research that has seen great advancements in the past few years.

2.caption: A Virtual Influencer, "Lil Miquela," Endorsing Prada

3.caption: The Verified Instagram Account of Zlatan Ibrahimović

6.caption: Jennifer Buscemi - One of the more popular Deepfake videos

7.caption: Synthetic Stock photos from Rosebud AI. None of these models are real.

2427379926.excerpt: Computers can generate faces that look real. What a time to be alive. As it becomes easier to do so, you can bet that the software will be used at some point for less innocent reasons. You should probably know how to tell the difference between fake and real.

2711518539.resolved_title: How to Spot a Perfect Fake: The World’s Top Art Forgery Detective
2711518539.excerpt: Forgeries have become so good – and so costly – that Sotheby’s has brought in its own in-house fraud-busting expert.

1.caption: The Frans Hals painting, Portrait of a Gentleman, supplied to Sotheby’s by Mark Weiss. It sold for a reported £8.5m

2777715733.resolved_title: The Hidden Signs That Can Reveal a Fake Photo
2777715733.excerpt: A picture may say a thousand words, but what if the photograph has been fabricated? There are ways to spot a fake – you just have to look closely enough.

2.caption: Two men exchanging some documents outside? Not necessarily. Credit: James O’Brien and Hany Farid.

3.caption: Some other types of fake are easier to spot, like this Time magazine cover that was found displayed in the US President's golf clubs. Credit: Washington Post/Twitter.

4.caption: Tracing the reflections in an image can make it easy to spot fakes if they don’t line up. Credit: Washington Post/Twitter.

5.caption: This photo of politician John Kerry was designed to mislead. Credit: Fourandsix.com.

6.caption: This photo of Barack Obama circulated in 2008, but is fake - the clock is a clue, a reference to a Hillary Clinton TV ad about picking up the phone at 3:00. Credit: Snopes.

7.caption: Doctored images emerged as Hurricane Sandy hit New York in 2012.

8.caption: Photo from the Library of Congress.

9.caption: Iran’s show of military might in 2008 was doctored to remove a launcher which failed to fire – and replaced with a fourth projectile. Courtesy: Fourandsix.com.

10.caption: This effect is not due to radiation, it's actually a natural process called fasciation. Credit: Candiru/Flickr/PD.

11.caption: This picture of Lee Harvey Oswald has often been claimed by conspiracy theorists to be a fake. Credit: Warren Commission/Wikipedia Commons.

12.caption: Hany Farid and his team showed that Lee Harvey Oswald’s stance in the photograph was entirely plausible and so conclude the photo was genuine. Credit: Hany Farid.

13.credit: tracing a line from a shadow in an image back to a light source, it is possible to see if something has been added to a picture.  Hany Farid

14.caption: This post originally appeared on BBC Future and was published June 29, 2017. This article is republished here with permission.Want to feel smarter every day?Visit BBC Future

3143047992.resolved_title: Hacked Billboards Can Make Teslas See 'Phantom Objects,' Causing Them to Swerve or Stop Abruptly
3143047992.excerpt: Security researchers have demonstrated how Tesla's Autopilot driver-assistance systems can be tricked into changing speed, swerving or stopping abruptly, simply by projecting fake road signs or virtual objects in front of them.

3136619774.excerpt: In 2019, two multimedia artists, Francesca Panetta and Halsey Burgund, set about to pursue a provocative idea. Deepfake video and audio had been advancing in parallel but had yet to be integrated into a complete experience.
